abstract: <jats:p>DNA barcode data is presented for Australian cetoniine flower beetles to aid with species discovery and guide revisionary taxonomy. Sequences of the COI gene’s DNA barcode region were acquired from 284 cetoniine specimens, covering 68 described species and 33 genera. This equates to 48% of the known species and 83% of the genera which occur in Australia. Results suggest up to 27 putative undescribed species in our sample, only 11 of which were suspected to be undescribed before this study, leaving 16 unexpected (“cryptic”) species. The Australian cetoniine fauna may hence be increased by up to 19%. An unanticipated result of the work is that each of the five most visible and commonly collected Australian cetoniine species, <jats:italic>Eupoecila australasiae</jats:italic> (Donovan, 1805), <jats:italic>Neorrhina punctatum</jats:italic> (Donovan, 1805), <jats:italic>Glycyphana (Glycyphaniola) stolata</jats:italic> (Fabricius, 1781), <jats:italic>Chondropyga dorsalis</jats:italic> (Donovan, 1805) and <jats:italic>Bisallardiana gymnopleura</jats:italic> (Fischer, 1823), have unexpectedly high diversity in DNA barcode sequences and were consequently split into multiple clusters, possibly indicating the presence of cryptic species.</jats:p>
title: Hiding in plain sight: DNA barcoding suggests cryptic species in all ‘well-known’ Australian flower beetles (Scarabaeidae: Cetoniinae)
